test_generations: Massimo Vignelli was born in Milan, Italy in 1931. He studied architecture at the Politecnico di Milano, graduating in 1954. After working in various design studios, he moved to the United States in 1960. He worked as a designer for many companies including IBM, American Airlines, Bloomingdale's, and Knoll. His most famous work is the subway map for the New York City Transit Authority. He died in 2014.

Freddie Mercury was born Farrokh Bulsara on September 5, 1946, in Zanzibar, Tanzania. His family moved to India when he was six years old, where his father worked as a cashier at British Airways. At age 17, Mercury joined a band called Ibex, which later changed its name to Queen. The band released their debut album in 1973, and they gained popularity after releasing their second album, 'Queen II,' in 1974. Their third album, 'Sheer Heart Attack,' was released in 1974, and it included the hit single "Killer Queen." In 1975, the band released their fourth album, 'A Night at the Opera,' which featured the hit singles "Bohemian Rhapsody" and "You're My Best Friend." Greta Gerwig was born in Sacramento, California, in 1983. She grew up in a family that encouraged her creativity, and at age 16, she moved to New York City to pursue acting. Gerwig began her film career in 2003, appearing in several independent films. Her breakthrough role came in 2012 when she starred in the critically acclaimed film 'Frances Ha,' which she also co-wrote. Gerwig has since appeared in many other films, including 'Mistress America,' 'Maggie's Plan,' and 'Lady Bird.' She has received numerous awards and nominations for her work, including an Academy Award nomination for Best Director for 'Lady Bird.'

José Alberto Mujica Cordano was born in Montevideo, Uruguay, on May 28, 1935. He studied law at the University of the Republic, graduating in 1961. After working as a lawyer, Mujica joined the Tupamaros guerrilla movement, which fought against the military dictatorship that ruled Uruguay from 1973 to 1985. He was arrested in 1974 and sentenced to 14 years in prison. Released in 1985, Mujica continued his political activities, becoming a member of the Broad Front coalition. In 2004, he was elected vice president of Uruguay, and in 2009, he won the presidential election. Mujica is known for his austere lifestyle, living in a modest house and driving a Volkswagen Beetle. He donates most of his salary to charity.

Alex Morgan was born in San Dimas, California on July 2, 1989. She began playing soccer at age four, and joined the youth team of the Orange County Soccer Club when she was eight years old. At age 14, she moved to Florida to join the Orlando Youth Soccer Association. In 2008, she graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, where she played college soccer for the Golden Bears. She was drafted into the Women's Professional Soccer league in 2011, and won the Rookie of the Year award that year. She also won the Golden Boot Award in 2012. In 2012, she made her debut with the U.S. women's national soccer team, and helped them win gold medals at the London Olympics and the 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup. She was named the Best Young Female Athlete ESPY Award in 2012.

Elon Reeve Musk was born in South Africa in 1971. His father was a civil engineer and his mother was a dietician. At age 10, Musk moved to Canada with his family. He studied at Queen's University in Ontario, but dropped out after two years to pursue his entrepreneurial dreams. In 1995, Musk founded Zip2 Corporation, which provided online content publishing software. In 1999, he co-founded PayPal, an online payment company that was acquired by eBay in 2002. In 2003, Musk founded SpaceX, a private space exploration company. In 2006, he founded Tesla Motors, an electric car manufacturer. In 2012, Musk founded SolarCity, a solar energy provider. In 2015, Musk announced plans to build a colony on Mars.

Cindy Sherman was born in 1954 in Glen Ridge, New Jersey. Her father was a pharmacist and her mother was a homemaker. At age 16, she began taking art classes at the State University of New York at Buffalo. After graduating, she moved to New York City where she worked as a receptionist and a waitress. In 1977, she enrolled in the Art Students League of New York, where she studied painting. In 1978, she had her first solo exhibition at the Metro Pictures Gallery. Since then, she has had numerous exhibitions around the world. She is known for her conceptual photography that explores issues of gender, sexuality, beauty, and society.

David Khari Webber Chappelle was born in Washington D.C., in 1973. His father worked at the Pentagon, while his mother was a professor at Howard University. At age 14, Chappelle began performing stand-up comedy, and soon after, he moved to New York City to pursue his dream. In 1993, he made his television debut on Def Comedy Jam, and in 1996, he released his first album, 'Rainbow Faces.' In 2003, Chappelle left his hit show 'Chappelle's Show,' which ran for two seasons, due to creative differences. He has since starred in several films, including 'The Nutty Professor II: The Klumps,' 'Blue Streak,' and 'You've Got Mail.'

Quentin Tarantino was born in Los Angeles, California, on March 27, 1963. His father worked as a TV actor, while his mother was a singer. At the age of 14, Tarantino began making short films. After graduating from high school, he moved to Manhattan Beach, where he worked at Video Archives, a video store. In 1984, Tarantino dropped out of film school and moved to L.A., where he worked as a movie usher. In 1987, he wrote and directed his first feature film, 'Reservoir Dogs,' which was released in 1992. The following year, he made 'Pulp Fiction,' which won the Palme d'Or at Cannes Film Festival. Since then, Tarantino has written and directed several other movies, including 'Jackie Brown,' 'Kill Bill,' and 'Django Unchained.'

Christiaan Barnard was born in South Africa in 1922. He studied medicine at the University of Cape Town, and graduated in 1946. After graduation, he worked as a surgeon in various hospitals in South Africa. In 1967, he performed the world's first human heart transplant. The patient survived for 18 days before dying due to complications. In 1968, Barnard performed another successful heart transplant. He retired from surgery in 1983, and died in 2001.
train_generations: Harvey Milk was born in Woodmere, Long Island, New York, on May 22, 1930. His family moved to San Francisco when he was 11 years old. After graduating from high school, Milk joined the Navy and served during the Korean War. Upon his return, he studied at the City College of San Francisco and graduated with a degree in business administration. In 1972, Milk ran for the Board of Supervisors and won. He was the first openly gay man elected to public office in California. On November 27, 1978, Milk and Mayor George Moscone were assassinated by Dan White, a former supervisor. The murder sparked outrage and led to the passage of the Briggs Initiative, which banned gays from teaching in California schools.

Priyanka Chopra was born in Jamshedpur, India, on July 18, 1982. Her father was an Indian army officer, while her mother was a physician. At age 17, she won the Miss India beauty pageant, which led to her acting debut in the movie The Hero: Love Story of a Spy. Since then, she has appeared in numerous Bollywood movies, including Andaaz, Krrish, Don, Fashion, and Barfi! She also starred in the American TV series Quantico. In 2016, she made her Hollywood debut in Baywatch.

George Washington was born in Westmoreland County, Virginia, on February 22, 1732. His father died when he was young, so his older brother Lawrence took care of him. At age 16, George enlisted in the British Army and fought in the French and Indian War. After the war, he returned home and inherited Mount Vernon, which he expanded into a large plantation. In 1759, he married Martha Custis, and they had two children together. In 1775, George Washington was appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army during the American Revolution. He led the army to victory over the British, and was unanimously elected as the first President of the United States in 1789. He served two terms, and retired to his estate at Mount Vernon. He died on December 14, 1799.

Frida Kahlo was born Magdalena Carmen Frieda Kahlo y Calderon in Mexico City in 1907. Her father was a German immigrant, while her mother was Mexican. At age sixteen, Frida contracted polio which left her right leg paralyzed. This led to a lifelong interest in art. In 1928, she married Diego Rivera, a famous muralist. The couple had a tumultuous marriage, but they remained together until his death in 1957. Frida Kahlo died in 1954 at the age of forty-seven. She is considered one of the most important artists of the twentieth century.

Slavoj Žižek is a Slovenian philosopher, cultural critic, and political activist. He was born in Ljubljana, Slovenia, in 1949. Žižek studied philosophy at the University of Ljubljana, where he received his PhD in 1982. He has taught at several universities around the world, including the University of London, the European Graduate School, and the University of Chicago. His work focuses on topics such as psychoanalysis, ideology, and global capitalism. He is also known for his appearances on television shows like The Colbert Report and Real Time with Bill Maher.

Born in Hong Kong in 1954, Jackie Chan is a Chinese actor, director, producer, martial artist, singer, stuntman, and philanthropist. Karl Marx was born in Trier, Germany, on May 5, 1818. His father was a lawyer, and his mother was a Jewish convert to Protestantism. At age 17, Marx began studying law at the University of Bonn. After graduating, he moved to Paris, where he met Friedrich Engels. The two men collaborated on the Communist Manifesto, which was published in 1848. Marx died in London on March 14, 1883.

Jamie Oliver was born in Essex, England, in 1975. At age 16, he won a scholarship to study at Westminster Catering College. After graduating, he worked at various restaurants in London before opening his own restaurant, The River Cafe, in 1997. In 1999, Oliver opened another restaurant, Fifteen, which trains young people in culinary arts. In 2005, Oliver began hosting the television show Jamie's Kitchen, where he teaches children how to cook healthy meals. In 2006, he published his first book, Jamie's Italy. In 2007, he released his second book, Jamie's Food Revolution. In 2009, he launched the campaign "Feed Me Better," which encourages parents to make healthier food choices for their children. John Maynard Keynes was born in Cambridge, England, in 1883. His father was a professor at Cambridge University, and his mother was a writer. Keynes studied at Eton College and King's College, Cambridge. After graduating, he worked as a civil servant in India, before returning to Cambridge to teach economics. In 1919, he published his most famous work, The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money. This book had a huge impact on economic thought, and it remains a standard textbook today. Keynes died in 1946.

A.R. Rahman is an Indian composer, singer, music producer, musician, and songwriter. He was born in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India, on January 6, 1966. His father was a classical musician, and his mother was a playback singer. Rahman began learning piano at age seven, and later learned violin, guitar, synthesizer, and drums. He also studied Western classical music. At age 11, Rahman won the National Talent Search Scholarship from Trinity College of Music, London. He released his debut album, titled 'Roja,' in 1992. The soundtrack was nominated for the Filmfare Award for Best Music Director. Rahman has composed over 100 film scores, including 'Slumdog Millionaire,' which won him two Academy Awards. He has also received numerous awards, including four National Film Awards, five Filmfare Awards, and six Academy Awards.

Thomas Edward Patrick Brady Jr. was born on August 3, 1977, in San Mateo, California. His father, Tom Sr., played football at Michigan State University, while his mother, Galynn, was a cheerleader there. Brady grew up in a family that loved sports, especially football. At the age of five, he began playing football with his dad. When he was nine years old, he joined the Pop Warner Little Scholars program. Brady attended Junipero Serra High School in San Mateo, where he played football, baseball, and basketball. After graduating high school, Brady enrolled at the University of Michigan, where he played college football for the Wolverines. In 2000, he won the Maxwell Award, given to the nation's top collegiate football player. The following year, he won the Heisman Trophy, awarded to the most outstanding player in college football. Elvis Aaron Presley was born in Tupelo, Mississippi, on January 8, 1935. His parents were Vernon and Gladys Presley. At age 13, Elvis began playing guitar and singing at local clubs. In 1954, he signed his first recording contract with Sun Records. In 1956, he released his first album, "Elvis Presley." The following year, he made his film debut in "Love Me Tender," which was a box office success. In 1958, he joined the army, but was discharged after a year due to poor health. After leaving the army, he continued to make movies and record albums. In 1968, he married Priscilla Beaulieu, and they had a daughter, Lisa Marie. In 1977, he retired from show business, and moved to Graceland, where he lived until his death in 1977.

Michael Joseph Jackson was born on August 29, 1958, in Gary, Indiana. His father, Joe Jackson, was a steel mill worker, while his mother, Katherine Jackson, was a devout Jehovah's Witness. The family moved to California when Michael was five years old. At age ten, Michael joined the Jackson Five, a popular singing group that included his brothers Jackie, Tito, Jermaine, Marlon, and Randy. The Jackson Five released their first album in 1968, and had several hits including "I Want You Back," "ABC," and "The Love You Save." In 1971, Michael Jackson left the group to pursue a solo career. His first solo album, "Got to Be There," was released in 1972. In 1979, Michael Jackson released the album "Off the Wall," which sold over 20 million copies worldwide. Paul Farmer is a physician and anthropologist who has worked extensively in Haiti since 1986. He is the co-founder of Partners in Health (PIH), which provides health care services to people living in poverty around the world. PIH has treated over 1 million patients in 10 countries. Farmer is also the chief of the Division of Global Health Equity at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He is the author of several books including 'Pathologies of Power,' 'To Repair the World,' and 'The Uses of Haiti.'

Amelia Earhart was born in Atchison, Kansas, on July 24, 1897. Her father was a lawyer and her mother was a social worker. She had two sisters and a brother. When she was young, she loved to read books about adventure and travel. She also liked to play sports such as softball and hockey. She graduated from high school at age 16. After graduation, she worked as a nurse’s aid in a hospital. She also worked as a telephone operator. In 1920, she took flying lessons and got her pilot license. She flew planes all over the country. In 1928, she set a world record for women pilots. She wanted to fly around the world. On June 1, 1937, she left from Harbor Grace, Newfoundland, Canada, in a plane called The Friendship. Charles Augustus Lindbergh was born in Detroit, Michigan, on February 4, 1902. His father was a lawyer and his mother was a teacher. At age 16, Lindbergh began flying lessons. In 1927, he flew across the Atlantic Ocean, becoming the first person to do so alone. The following year, he won the Pulitzer Prize for his book 'We." In 1935, Lindbergh married Anne Morrow, the daughter of Dwight Morrow, a former ambassador to Mexico. Together they had four children. During World War II, Lindbergh worked for the U.S. Army Air Corps. After the war, he became a consultant for Pan American Airlines. In 1954, Lindbergh was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal. He died in 1974.

Born in Beijing, China, in 1963, Li Lianjie (Jet Li) began his martial arts training at age six. At age 12, he won the national wushu championship. After graduating from high school, he joined the Beijing Wushu Team and toured internationally. In 1982, he made his film debut in Shaolin Temple. Since then, he has starred in over 100 films, including Fist of Legend, Romeo Must Die, and The One. His most recent movie is The Expendables 2.

Petra Cortright was born in 1986 in California. She studied at the University of California, Santa Cruz, where she received her Bachelor of Arts degree in Film and Digital Media. Her work has been exhibited internationally, including at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York City. She lives and works in Los Angeles.
